Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 45158-001 
Research and Development Technical Assistance (RDTA) 
November 2011 
 
 
 
Strengthening Economic Assessment Capacity for 
Asia and the Pacific Region
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  ADO  –  Asian Development Outlook 
  DMC  –  developing member country  
ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
TA  –  technical assistance 
   
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Research and development technical assistance (RDTA) 
Targeting classification  –  General intervention 
Sector (subsector)  –  Multisector (economic and public affairs management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting macroeconomic stability), regional 
cooperation and integration (trade and investments, money and 
finance), capacity development (organizational development) 
Location (impact)  –  National (high), regional (high)

Vice-President  U. Schäfer-Preuss,  Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development

Director  J. Zveglich, Jr., Assistant Chief Economist, Macroeconomics and

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Guided by Strategy 2020,1 the Asian Development Bank (ADB) focuses on three critical 
strategic  agendas—inclusive  economic  growth,  environmentally  sustainable  growth,  and 
regional integration—to serve as a partner and agent for change in Asia and the Pacific. ADB 
has expanded its role as a knowledge bank, providing more advice to its member countries on 
critical economic issues and policies. 
 
2.  ADB  has  the  unique  ability  to  contribute  and  apply  development  knowledge  in 
developing Asia because it is centrally positioned to identify trends within and across the region. 
It provides firsthand insights and analyses of economic developments and prospects, as well as 
an impartial institutional outlook that goes beyond individual countries. However, ADB’s capacity 
to produce macroeconomic projections remains limited. It still relies on economic projections 
based on models developed by other institutions including the International Monetary Fund and 
Oxford Economics, consensus forecasts by Consensus Economics, and government estimates. 
With the remarkable progress in the development of economic assessment tools particularly 
since mid-1990s, it is time for ADB to improve its tools for short- to medium-term projections and 
policy evaluations. This research and development technical assistance (TA)2 will provide ADB 
with the capacity and proper tools to help developing Asian countries and their economic 
authorities better understand the business cycles of their national and regional economies, and 
facilitate strategic decision making that affects a wide range of economic policies.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  ADB’s Economics and Research Department (ERD) releases its economic outlook for 
developing  member  countries  (DMCs)  in  Asia  and the  Pacific  twice  annually  in  the  Asian 
Development Outlook (ADO) report and its update. The ADO provides projections for important 
macroeconomic  variables  such  as  gross  domestic  product,  inflation,  and  current  account 
balance for the following 2 years. These projections currently are provided by ADB’s regional 
departments, except for the projections for Hong Kong, China; Republic of Korea; Singapore; 
and Taipei,China, which are done by ERD. While ADB has strived to enhance its capacity to 
produce  forecasts,  its  ability  to  conduct  policy  analyses  and  produce  macroeconomic 
projections remains limited and varies across departments. 
 
4.  ERD has taken a series of initiatives since early 2000s to strengthen ADB’s forecasting 
capacity. These include subscribing to the Global Economic Model of Oxford Economics in 2002, 
which  ERD  has  routinely  used  to  produce  baseline  assumptions  for  major  industrialized 
economies and to cross-check some of the DMCs’ projections in the ADO and its update. 
Another initiative is the Regional Economic Outlook Task Force. It was established in late 2008 
to improve communication between ERD and the staff members of regional departments in 
charge of ADO chapters. During task force meetings, regular discussions on important events 
occurring within and outside Asia and the Pacific helped facilitate better assessments of the 
economic  conditions  of  each  DMC.  In  addition  to  these  ERD  initiatives,  some  regional 
departments also initiated macroeconomic modeling exercises for the People’s Republic of 
China and Pakistan to improve their understanding of the economy and the projections made.

Manila. www.adb.org/strategy2020/ 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 August 2011.

2   
5.  Despite these initiatives, ADB still needs to improve its tools for short- to medium-term 
projections  and  policy  evaluations.  Since  2006,  three  technical  notes3 that  evaluated  the 
forecasting performance of the ADO identified the need to improve the methods used by ADB. A 
technical note in 2009, which reviewed economic assessment tools in general and past and 
present practices at ADB, also highlighted the need to construct forecasting models that are 
designed or based on the economic peculiarities of each DMC.4 In addition to these limitations, 
the Global Economic Model of Oxford Economics used by ERD only provides forecasts for 10 
DMCs.  
 
6.  Strengthening ADB’s economic assessment capacity is essential to improving the quality 
of ADB’s flagship publication (the ADO and its update) and policy analyses. It will also improve 
the inputs provided to other important ADB publications, such as the Asia Economic Monitor 
(two editions annually) and the Pacific Economic Monitor (three editions annually). Since the 
ADO  was first  published  in  1989, government  officials,  development partners,  economists, 
academics,  think  tanks,  private  sector  entities,  and  the  media  have  grown  increasingly 
interested in the publication. Because of the continued robust growth in Asia and the Pacific, 
ADB’s views on the economic outlook, policy challenges, and development challenges in the 
region  are  increasingly  cited  and  scrutinized.  Creating  tools  for  short-  to  medium-term 
projections and policy evaluations will greatly contribute to ADB's research. 
 
7.  If  ADB’s  economic  assessment  tools  are  designed  or  based  on  the  economic 
peculiarities of each DMC, the ADO’s importance to Asian policy makers will be enhanced. 
Existing work by international agencies and other ADB departments will be extended or used 
extensively as a guide in designing such tools. The resulting tool set will directly complement 
the existing tools and help countries improve their understanding of the factors affecting Asia’s 
short- to medium-term economic prospects. It will also help elevate the public’s perception of 
ADB as a prime knowledge bank within and outside developing Asia. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of this TA will be the provision of more effective policy advice based on 
enhanced economic assessment tools and tailor-made projections for developing Asia, which 
will influence the intellectual environment in which policy formulation occurs and promote ADB 
as an authoritative and independent source of knowledge about the region. The impact can be 
measured by an evaluation of whether economic policies and development strategies adopted 
by ADB's DMCs are consistent with what the results of this study indicate. 
 
9.  The  outcome  of  this  TA  will  be  robust  economic  assessment  tools  and  better 
understanding of the short- to medium-term key macroeconomic components of the regional 
economy to facilitate strategic decisions that affect a wide range of economic policies.  
 
10.  The main outputs of this TA are forecasting tools for gross domestic product and inflation 
for developing countries in Asia and the Pacific.

Forecasting Performance of Asian Development Outlook. Manila; and ADB. 2008. Asian Development Outlook

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have two components that aim to build economic assessment capacity and 
develop new tools that can cater to the peculiarities of economies in Asia and the Pacific. Under 
the first component, technical workshops on economic assessment capacity building will be 
organized. This component will focus on capacity building of regional and country offices in 
charge of preparing macroeconomic assessments and projections for the ADO as well as other 
relevant officials in the region. Two technical workshops will aim to introduce tools that can be 
used to conduct economic assessments and generate projections. These include easy-to-use 
modeling tools based on Microsoft Excel and dynamic stochastic general equilibrium modeling. 
These complementary tools will help with diagnostic analyses of macroeconomic performance 
and of the effects of macroeconomic and structural policies on the main variables of interest to 
policymakers, including output, prices, and the balance of payments.  
12.  Under  the  second  component,  studies  will  generate  (i)  a  multicountry  economic 
assessment tool that will serve as a framework to check consistency across projections for ADB 
member countries and global assumptions, and (ii) two tools for projections and policy analyses 
for low- and middle-income country groups in the region.5 One additional workshop is planned 
under the TA, in which consultants, ADB staff, and other experts will discuss and present the 
economic assessment tools they generated as part of the second component. 
13.  The objective of the TA is to improve stakeholders’ understanding of which development 
strategies and policies are most effective in minimizing extreme business cycle fluctuations and 
achieving  inclusive  and  sustained  economic  growth.  Options  for  alternative  development 
strategies and policies will be made available to policy makers and practitioners, which will allow 
them to assess which alternative development strategies would be relevant for their economies. 
The study will provide strategies for national development as well as for regional cooperation 
and integration.    
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $650,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The financing will cover the 
remuneration, per diem, and travel expenses of international consultants, as well as the travel 
expenses  of  ADB  team  members  who  will  act  as  resource  persons,  travel  expenses  of 
conference  and  workshop  resource  persons,  report  production,  and  other  miscellaneous 
expenses. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency;  ERD’s  Macroeconomics  and  Finance  Research 
Division, in close coordination with regional departments, will be the implementing agency. The 
TA will build on the inputs of the consultants hired for this project and ADB team members, 
including those in regional departments. Counterpart institutions will not play a substantive role 
except in workshops and other forums where collaboration with DMC governments and other 
stakeholders, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, will be sought 
either in the form of input or participation. The TA will be implemented over 20 months from 
                                                
5 The selection of economies that belong to low- and middle-income country groups will be determined in consultation 
with the Office of Regional Economic Integration and other relevant departments in ADB.

4   
December 2011 to June 2013.6 The projections and policy analyses generated from this TA 
could be used as inputs for ADB's future research, including the ADO and its update.   
 
16.  The TA will require 5 person-months of international consulting. One lead consultant (an 
economist)  will  be  hired  for  1  person-month  to  coordinate  the  technical  aspects  from 
conceptualization of the projection to evaluation of the economic assessments. Four consultants 
(economists)  will  be  hired  for  1  person-month  each  to  conceptualize,  design,  and  build 
economic assessment tools. A national consultant will be hired for 12 person-months to help 
with the logistics and organizational matters, and to provide research assistance.  
 
17.  ADB will hire the consultants individually in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants are in Appendix 3. Disbursements under the project will follow ADB’s Technical 
Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will use 
existing software (e.g., Stata 11) and databases (e.g., CEIC Database, Bloomberg), but will also 
purchase other essential software (e.g., Matlab, scientific workplace) and computer equipment. 
These purchases will be made in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time) and in coordination with ADB’s Office of Information Systems and 
Technology and Office of Administrative Services, where applicable. The equipment purchased 
under the TA will be turned over to ADB upon completion of the project. 
 
18.  The expected outputs and outcome evaluation will be disseminated in conferences and 
workshops where the consultants will present their economic assessment tools. These events 
and related follow-up discussions will provide opportunities for exchanges between TA research 
staff,  consultants,  and  local  stakeholders.  Participation  of  regional  departments  and  DMC 
officials will be emphasized and expected in the two technical workshops, which will allow them 
to benefit from the TA. The concluding conference will serve as a broader platform for dialogue 
and evaluation of the TA. Other dissemination activities, including publication of the edited 
output and media exposure if necessary, will be conducted in cooperation with the Department 
of External Relations. The outcome evaluation will be gathered by soliciting comments on 
designed economic assessment tools from international and local experts, if possible from other 
research  and  academic  institutions.  A  peer  review  within  ADB  to  assess  the  quality  and 
applicability of the tools will also be sought.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening Economic Assessment Capacity for Asia and the Pacific Region, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

from that country.

8  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
I.  Lead Economist (1, 1 person-month) 
1.  The lead economist should have proven track record serving as a project advisor or 
team leader in similar assignments. Under the supervision of the project team leader, the lead 
economist will 
(i)  provide leadership to the team of economists engaged by the project in terms of 
conceptualization, design, and conduct of projections and policy evaluations for 
the developing countries in Asia and the Pacific; 
(ii)  facilitate collaboration between the team of economists engaged by the project 
and the project team in the Asian Development Bank (ADB); 
(iii)  discuss strategic aspects of  the study with ADB; 
(iv)  help ADB staff coordinate their work; 
(v)  ensure that comments from the workshops are incorporated in the final reports; 
and  
(vi)  participate in the workshops organized under  the research and development 
technical assistance. 
 
2.  The lead economist should have (i) a doctorate in economics; (ii) expert knowledge of 
development issues in developing countries in Asia; (iii) proven capacity for both quantitative 
and policy-oriented analysis; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues and identify 
key policy messages for policy makers, development partners, and other stakeholders. 
 
II.  Economists (4, 4 person-months total) 
 
3.  Under  the  supervision  of  the  lead  economist,  four  international  experts  will  be 
responsible for conceptualizing, designing, and undertaking two models for low- and middle-
income groups, and one structural macroeconomic model. The economists will participate in 
workshops to present the findings of their research studies. 
 
4.  Each economist should have (i) a doctorate in economics; (ii) expert knowledge of 
development issues in developing countries in Asia; (iii) proven capacity for both quantitative 
and policy-oriented analysis; and (iv) proven capacity to synthesize complex issues and identify 
key policy messages for policy makers, development partners, and other stakeholders. 
 
III.  Resource Persons (10, 2.5 person-months total) 
 
5.    Under the supervision of the project team leader, 10 resource persons will be hired to 
participate in the workshops. The resource persons should have (i) expert knowledge of the 
sector and of development issues in Asia, and (ii) extensive experience in macroeconomic 
modeling and development policy. 
 
B.  National Consultant (1, 12 person-months) 
 
6.  The  economics  consultant  should  have  excellent  working  experience  in  general 
economics. Under the direct supervision of relevant Macro-economics and Finance Research 
Division (ERMF) staff, the consultant will assist in the economic research work of the technical 
assistance.
